newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy raises 7.698 trln lire from Eni sale.
newsitem.headline: Italy raises 7.698 trln lire from Eni sale.

text.p: The Treasury said it raised 7.698 trillion lire from the sale of 14 percent of its stake in oil and chemicals group ENI in Italy's largest privatisation to date.

Treasury Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi told a news conference institutional investors were allocated 400 million shares. They paid 7,161 lire per share -- the closing price for ENI on Friday on the Milan bourse.
Retail investors were allocated 700 million shares at a price of 6,910 lire per share.
"This was the biggest retail sale ever carried out on the Italian market and the biggest share offer yet seen in Italy," said Mario Draghi, the director general of the Treasury.

The overall value of the sale looks set to rise thanks to a reserve of 165 million additional shares which will be offered to institutions, under an over-allotment, or "green shoe", option, drawn up in the case of heavy demand.
"I think there's a good chance all the green shoe will be taken up," said one of the ENI global organisers, who declined to be named.

Ciampi told reporters that if all the green shoe was sold, the Treasury would raise a total 8.88 trillion lire from the second tranche sale. The Treasury placed an initial 15 percent of ENI on the market last November at 5,250 lire per share.
If all the green show was sold, the Treasury would be left with a 69 percent stake in ENI.
"This is the biggest second tranche placement ever seen in Europe and the largest fully-paid placement in the world," Ciampi said.
The Treasury decided to increase the size of the offering by 57 percent mid-week because of heavy demand for the stock, especially from retail investors.
Originally Italy planned to sell just 700 million shares, with 250 million of these earmarked for small investors and the rest for institutions.

Draghi said the institutional offering had been oversubscribed by a total three times but did not give details. He said final allocations would be decided between now and Monday morning when the new shares will start trading.

One of the global advisors said he did not think any single institutional investor would finish with more than a one percent stake in ENI. He added that demand from U.S. and British institutions had been especially strong.
Ciampi said proceeds from the sale would go to a special sinking fund set up to reduce Italy's huge debt mountain.
The Treasury said ENI employees, who were offered especially favourable terms, had applied for around 84 million shares. ENI employees as a block now hold more than one percent of the group's stock.
Ciampi said the government would push ahead with plans to sell telecom holding Stet by March 1997, with electricity group Enel following afterwards.
"We are hopeful that as the privatisation programme continues...we will reach our objective of one million shareholders (in Italy)," Draghi said.
